node.title: External mesh file - merging blocks?

node.bodyText: @travismui

@rui-hu
do you know people who have experience with using SAM and .geo (gmsh files)

Hi @GiudGiud, sorry for the radio silence. We're in the process of resolving this internally, @aiskhak is actually one of our affiliate students. It seems like this was a SAM-related input syntax issue, if we find any relevant info for the larger community we'll try to share it here.
Sorry for not reporting. The problem is caused by sharp mesh transition regions. The generation of unstructured grids without sharp transitions resolved the issue. Thanks, everyone.

node.title: How to export small strain component using auxkernel RankTwoAux?
node.bodyText:
Dear,
I want to export strain tensor component using RankTwoAux auxkernel. How can I do that? I only know the way with stress like below:
Aux variable definition:

Aux kernel :

Material stress tensor calculation:

I suppose the logic is first define aux variable, then use auxkernels RankTwoAux to get tensor component for the variable, while the tensor is come from the material object ComputeLinearElasticStress. But I don't know how to use the same logic in the strain.
Any response will be highly appreciated!
zhigang

Hello
You should have a look at the tests in the tensor mechanics module.
Like these ones:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/ad_anisotropic_plasticity/anis_plasticity_test.i
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/global_strain/global_strain_disp.i
@jiangwen84 will probably know a better one for small strain.
Guillaume

@GiudGiud  pointed you to the right examples.
Simplest way is to use TensorMechanicsAction
[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
[all]
strain = SMALL
add_variables = true
incremental = true
generate_output = 'elastic_strain_xx elastic_strain_yy elastic_strain_xy stress_xx stress_xy stress_yy'
[]
[]

Sorry for late reply! Too many examinations these days.
Many thanks for your help, I will try that!
Best,
zhigang

node.title: Linear strain-softening -Mohr Coulomb
node.bodyText: How can I implement linear strain-softening to Mohr-Coulomb failure criterion?
You can take a look at this example: moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/mohr_coulomb/uni_axial2.i
Thank you for sharing this. Found a similar example using TensorMechanicsHardeningExponential.

node.title: Product and Team naming conventions
node.bodyText:
I know this is not a technical question, so if there is a better venue, I'm all ears. I work at Sandia Labs on the Sierra suite of codes, which is somewhat similar to MOOSE in scope and functionality. I had some question about naming conventions:

I was wondering how you came up with the module names: bison, falcon, etc.
Do you structure your teams around the modules?

If not, do they have team names and how did those team names come about?



It seems like there is some continuity with your naming that we'd like to explore on our side.
Thanks,
Ryan
@friedmud

I don't think it's all that different from Sierra naming - which shouldn't be surprising since I came from Sandia, working on Sierra 😄
FALCON, BISON, Pronghorn, etc. are applications that utilize the framework and are effectively equivalent to Adagio, Aria, etc. at Sandia.  They are code names - and they are typically the names of the code teams (depends on the size of the application - some are small and are only developed by one person).
When we can we try to make them acronyms and have them be animals from Idaho.  MOOSE came first (Multiphysics Object-Oriented Simulation Environment) then BISON (recursive acronym: BISON Implicit Simulation Of Nuclear-Fuel), etc.  But - many (like Pronghorn) are just animal names and aren't acronyms.
The animal names have proven a good choice since people all over the world can pick animal names that are meaningful to them (like the mascot of their school, or an animal that is only in their area, etc.)
Let me know if somehow I missed the intent of your question!

node.title: Get error in compile test of MOOSE installation
node.bodyText:
I got this error in MOOSE installation. Would you please let me know how can I fix it?
Sincerely,
Sajjad
`(moose) sajjad@sajjad-PC:~$ conda install moose-tools
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): failed
UnavailableInvalidChannel: The channel is not accessible or is invalid.
channel name: moose
channel url: https://mooseframework.org/conda/moose
error code: 404
You will need to adjust your conda configuration to proceed.
Use conda config --show channels to view your configuration's current state,
and use conda config --show-sources to view config file locations.
`

That is an old channel. Please run the following to remove it and recreate your environment:
conda deactivate
conda env remove -n moose
conda config --remove channels https://mooseframework.org/conda/moose
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda create --name moose -q -y
conda activate moose
conda install moose-tools
conda install moose-libmesh

Sorry for the trouble. I'll make an issue so that in the future we have this information on the site.

Many thanks,
Now I got stuck with a new problem
at the last step to 'make -j4' there is the following passage and 'run test' failed.
Any advice?
Linking Executable /home/sajjad/projects/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/exodiff... /home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/lib/libcrypto.so.1.1: undefined reference to clock_gettime@GLIBC_2.17'
/home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/lib/libcrypto.so.1.1: undefined reference to __fdelt_chk@GLIBC_2.15' /home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/lib/libssl.so.1.1: undefined reference to memcpy@GLIBC_2.14'
/home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/lib/libcrypto.so.1.1: undefined reference to getauxval@GLIBC_2.16' /home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/sajjad/miniconda3/envs/moose/lib/libcrypto.so.1.1: undefined reference to secure_getenv@GLIBC_2.17'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
/home/sajjad/projects/moose/framework/moose.mk:370: recipe for target '/home/sajjad/projects/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/exodiff' failed
make: *** [/home/sajjad/projects/moose/framework/contrib/exodiff/exodiff] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
(moose) sajjad@sajjad-PC:~/projects/moose/test$
`

You have stale artifacts in the build that used the old environment that you need to clean up. Do this to clean them up:
cd ~/projects/moose
make clobberall

Then, recompile and try again.

I've got this error
(moose) sajjad@sajjad-PC:~/projects/moose$ make clobberall make: *** No rule to make target 'clobberall'.  Stop.

Whoops:
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make clobberall
I did it, but there is the same error

weird. moose/test should have a makefile.
Can you tell us what ls ~/projects/moose/test returns
if these is a makefile there you should definitely be able to make clobberall then make again

Please let me tell you the complete history:
I already had MOOSE, and it worked properly on the application I had. I made a new application and tried to activate some modules in the make file. But the make command returned nothing (There was no compiling file after changing the module in the make file).
I gave up and backed to the previous application. But I've got some weird errors to compile the new *.C files. I supposed I had to update moose to solve the problem, where I got several errors to connect the moose repositories. On the first try, it was error 500, and then it was 000 and 404.
I uninstalled moose, then updated Linux and tried to install it again, where I got the error 404 to connect the moose repository (First discussion). With your help and  Troubleshooting guideline, it was solved, and MOOSE was installed, but in the make step, there were some unfinished jobs and failed (following lines), and the run-tests failed (errors are at the end).
Note that I tried to fix the problem with the make clobberall and the Build Issues and Failing Tests solution ways, but I have got the same error. Even I uninstalled and reinstalled moose and conda again, and there was the same error.
I passed a day full of errors, and now I am confused.
Would you please let me know how I can fix this problem?
I am looking forward to hearing from you,
and Thanks in advance for your kind support.
### last lines of meke step where you can see the error

Hi,
I just wanted to let you know that I have exactly the same problem and I'm interested in knowing how to solve it.

What Arch/Version of Linux are you both running on? If you are unsure, and even if you are not can you try the following command and report back the results
lsb_release -a
I am also interested in your Conda environments. Can you post the results of the following command as well:
conda info --all

node.title: Prescribing value on a set of nodes
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I was wondering, is it possible to prescribe the values of a variable on an edge not by selecting the edge by name and then giving a value or function, but actually to use a node list and corresponding value list for each node? So something like:
[BCs]
  [prescribed]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    node_ids = '0 1 2 3 4'
    values = '0 0.1 0.2 0.3 0.4'
  []
[]

Thanks for your help.

Dear @tairoon1
You need to look into the MeshGenerators,
normally I use this one:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/meshgenerators/SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator.C
in which I set the coordinates for a box, and the nodes inside are added to a node set.
I cannot see any MeshGenerator in the framework that can work with the node ids, but should not be too difficult to make,
you should also check in the modules.
I am quite sure the solution will not be to add the ids to a BC, but using a MeshGenerator.
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Docs for the one @ngrilli suggested, I would do it that way too
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator.html
This one works with ids but you need to specify the ids for ALL elements
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/SubdomainIDGenerator.html
EDIT : that last one is for block ids. We could make a new one for sideset IDs though

Thank you for the replies. If I understand correctly, then the MeshGenerators allows you to select a node set. Assuming now, I have that node set, how could I then prescribe values onto each degree of freedom of each node?

Dear @tairoon1
A MeshGenerator object always provides a name for the newly created node set.
You can use that name in the boundary conditions.
You can see an example here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/test/tests/neper/polycrystalneper.i
Note the line:
"new_boundary = x0"
Best Regards,
Nicolò

So you'll have to create a DirichletBC for every nodeset you created. As long as there s like less than 1000 it should be fine speedwise.
If there are a lot of nodes you want to specify, you may want to either:

write a script to write the input file
write an Action (in moose, in C++) to make it create the nodesets and the dirichlet BC from just a vector

I see, thank you for your replies. I think I understand now how it works. I was hoping that it would be possible to directly specify directly given a list of node_ids/dof_ids and then a list of values, but I guess that would be quite specific. Thanks for your help!

node.title: Updating material property name from "thermal_conductivity" to "thermal_conductivity_tensor"
node.bodyText:
Does anyone mind if I update the declared and extracted material property name (type RankTwoTensor) from "thermal_conductivity" to "thermal_conductivity_tensor" in the AnisoHeatConductionMaterial and AnisoHeatConduction kernel?
@dschwen let me know if you are fine with the following change?
The following code in AnisoHeatConductionMaterial
_thermal_conductivity(
    declareGenericProperty<RankTwoTensor, is_ad>(_base_name + "thermal_conductivity")),
_dthermal_conductivity_dT(
    declarePropertyDerivative<RankTwoTensor>(_base_name + "thermal_conductivity", _T_name)),

and in AnisoHeatConduction kernel
_k(getMaterialProperty<RankTwoTensor>("thermal_conductivity")),
_dk_dT(getMaterialPropertyDerivative<RankTwoTensor>("thermal_conductivity", _var.name()))

will change to:
_thermal_conductivity(
    declareGenericProperty<RankTwoTensor, is_ad>(_base_name + "thermal_conductivity_tensor")),
_dthermal_conductivity_dT(
    declarePropertyDerivative<RankTwoTensor>(_base_name + "thermal_conductivity_tensor", _T_name)),


_k(getMaterialProperty<RankTwoTensor>("thermal_conductivity_tensor")),
_dk_dT(getMaterialPropertyDerivative<RankTwoTensor>("thermal_conductivity_tensor", _var.name()))

That's gonna be inconsistent with the existing naming convention IMHO. For example, we have "stress" instead of "stress_tensor", "eigenstrain_names" instead of "eigenstrain_tensor_names". Is the original name "thermal_conductivity" causing you trouble? If so, I'm fine with renaming it.

node.title: Porous Flow-nonlinear solver does not coverge
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to develop a hydromechanical model based on Porous Flow THM example. Model runs but non-linear solver does not converge.  My Input&Mesh file available here.
How can I solve this issue?
Thanks

Hello
Have you consulted the following pages
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/stabilization.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/nonlinear_convergence_problems.html
Guillaume
after scaling, not it is working fine.  Thank you!

node.title: Linking variables with a multiplier at an interface.
node.bodyText:
I am relatively new to MOOSE and am looking to implement a steady-state multiplier at an interface, to link two variables.  Specifically, i'm looking to model a scenario where, for an interface between two regions A and B with variable u in region A and variable v in region B, the boundary condition on v at the interface is a function of the value of variable u at the interface.  There also needs to be a mass flux conservation condition at the boundary, however that can be handled using the InterfaceDiffusionFluxMatch interface kernel.  The function takes other variables, e.g. temperature and volume, and so cannot be implemented using the function kernels, as I understand that these only take variables (x, y, z, t).  As this is an equilibrium situation and we can effectively ignore rate effects, the InterfaceReaction interface kernel is not suitable.
It strikes me that this should be relatively straightforward to do - has anyone any experience of this problem?  Many thanks.
**Specifically, this is to implement Sieverts Law at the interface, where C = K * SQRT( P )
C is the concentration in region B (v) and P is the gas pressure in region A (u).

Hello
You may want to consult this discussion #18799
to choose between a BC object and an interface kernel with a penalty factor.
InterfaceReaction could easily be modified to penalize the difference between C and K sqrt(P)
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Many thanks for this.  Would you be able to point me in the direction of some guidance on modifying kernels, for those that are new to this?
Luke

Here's some guidelines for kernels. Interfqace kernels are similar except they are only ran at interface
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Kernels/
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/InterfaceKernels/ for interface kernels but it s not as detailed
How is this going?
This has turned out well - with minor modification the combination of InterfaceDiffusion and InterfaceReaction are giving the results I need.  Many thanks for your help.

node.title: Question about Isotropic Power Hardening stress update
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I have a question about how IsotropicPowerHardeningStressUpdate material is setup. As far as I can see, this particular class is used to calculate the yield stress based on the strength coefficient and strain hardening exponent. My question is how is the inelastic strain calculated while using this class? Is it directly inherited from IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate?
Thanks,
Bala
The IsotropicPowerHardeningStressUpdate inherits from IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate. The inelastic strain is calculated using the return mapping algorithm.
